description: It wont grab an image file. Same problem described my Anatly in December 2020.

I tried it, despite it mentioned only "Any Debian based", some reviewer said it worked on all ISO's he tried, so I tried (not knowing if he had tried other than "Debian Based" - however some couldn't get a single ISO to loaded, while others seemed to get "first one it found" (which I'm assuming meant the first one in the directory, no matter which file he picked). Some complained not getting all or even any USB devices available.

Here's my experience:
No USB devices visible. However, I unplugged my old Gentoo Live USB stick, plugged it back in, and sure enough it came visible.
Then I tried to add the ISO file "install-amd64-minimal-20210127T214504Z.iso", which is the latest Gentoo install CD image - it won't add it, just plain refuses.... I can select it, but it's not adding it!

And as this USB boot stick writer was so promising, in that unlike any other I've tried on Linux, since unetbootin, which hasn't been kept up to date and will faul to write any modern ISO's, hasn't been able to write to the partition already on the USB stick, but uses 'dd', which will literally overwrite the USB stick with the partition on the ISO file. That means when you write an ISO that is 20% of the devices storage capacity, you will get an USB stick with no space left and only has 20% of the space used - you have to empty and reformat the stick to gain space.
This software advertises that it will leave rest of the space free and available, meaning it uses the more intelligent mentod than the dreaded 'dd' method, SO IT'S AWESOME.

The ONLY PROBLEM I have with this program is that IT DOESN'T WORK AT ALL! Total waste of time, why does Ubuntu offer software that hasn't been properly tested to work anyway!?

If the ISO does not happen to match certain exacting criteria (you are trying to make a bootable USB stick for an OS not on it's internal approved list), this startup disk creator will fail to do anything.

TL;DR: Good for making linux bootable disks, not so much for other OSes when you need one of them for a client's machine (and they will NOT approve of having Linux installed for some batshit crazy reason).
